reviewText:
A friend of mine once remarked that there's no way to describe this game that still makes it sound fun once you've explained it. By all reason, Papers Please shouldn't be as much of a good time as it is. You serve as an unnamed male citizen of the Arstozkan Empire, employed by lottery to rigorously scan and verify documents at the newest border crossing station in your dystopian, communist nation circa the 1980s. The names are all changed, but you essentially control Checkpoint Charlie at the Berlin Wall, and it's your job to make sure illegal immigration in your sector grinds to a halt. If you fail, your impoverished family will starve and freeze even worse than they already do.

But in spite of all its Cold War doom and gloom, Papers Please is a wonderfully intricate and engaging experience. The charm and humor of its characters, such as the permanently cheerful Jorgi Costava or the irascible Dimitri (Your supervisor, who stops by to inform you how bad you're doing each week) draws you in with each passport you process. Soon, you're reading your employee handbook to pass the time, determined to serve your country well and provide for your family. Or maybe you begin working undercover with the resistance, smuggling revolutionaries into the country with falsified papers. Or maybe you set up a smuggling business with a few regular border-crossers, and plan to flee the country yourself.

With 20 different endings to unlock and hundreds of stories to hear, Papers Please is unique kind of game; one that defies the genres of the medium and forces us to think differently about our entertainment. I highly recommend you pick it up. And remember! Always read the daily bulletin!

Glory to Arstotzka!

reviewText: This is one of the most unique games to come around in many years. reviewText: It is a dark age of communism.  Your country has just ended hostilities with its neighbor and are now allowing travel into the country.  You are in control at the Berl...I mean Grestin Wall.  Not by choice, but by threat of death if you are not able to provide for your family or if you even inadvertantly perform the tiniest act that may be traitorous.  Slight missteps result in citations that take away what little money you are paid to support your family.  Enjoy the great communist pasttime of:  Food or Heat?  Will your family starve or freeze?  All up to you in this dystopian masterpiece that is a lot better than I have described.  Yet it is exactly as I described it, but for some reason it is one of the most addictive games I've played in awhile; fair warning, it can be repetive and menial and I have some minor OCD which could be why I enjoyed it.

reviewText: I'm so conflicted... I love this game, even though it makes me feel very depressed/apprehensive about things. The reason why I like it so is beause of the masterful way the story is told. Games are a unique storytelling medium because of the level of interactivity. Really, no other media has that level of interaction (movies, books, comics, theater, music). What makes this game special is that through its mechanics and gameplay, the story unfolds. Line, hook and sinker the mechanics get you before you realize you're in too deep.\n\nOverall, if you play games for them to invoke some sort of emotion... This is it. Highly recomended.

reviewText:
Start playing this game and think it's easy.
Spend 5 minutes in it and realise you're not paying attention, so you get a notice from the government.
Begin to spend more time on details. The day is over.
Notice how you earn less money because you took too much to inspect so few people.
Basic needs like food and rent need to be paid.
Get to work again and rush more people. Make mistakes; The government is all over you.

This game is amazingly fun and a real exercise to your brain.Try to memorise all the provinces of the different countries (good luck) and the game will tip you off your chair with more government rules.
Though some things are easy to check once you get the hang of it, when pressure starts to build up the game will break your concentration with some hilarious comments, love stories or pure  eyebrow rising momments from the immigrants.

All in all, this game has simple repeat step X and Y to achieve goal, but all of those steps may or may not come for each of the immingrants you need to inspect, and even if they appear, they will be in a random order.
This is what really makes you think.

The game has Story Mode and Endless Mode.
You will also have an option to enable easy mode"."

reviewText: Papers, Please is the game that made me think I'm a terrible person. This game simulates a life in a totalitarian regime where you work on the border, deciding people's lives.  If you do good and let people who don't have a passport but want to go over the border continue, your pay will be deducted. If you don't have money, your family will starve, and if you don't have money to pay the bills you will be arrested. On the other hand, if you don't help the people you will feel like you are a terrible person. I made this mistake once in the game, and never again. I destroyed their regime, saved my family, but alas my son has died.\nI would recommend this game to everyone to check their moral codex, and especially to people in rich countries, so they can know what is like living in poverty.

reviewText:
Papers, please is a unique and interesting game, you're basically a one man border control and trust me, it gets more interesting...
Just looking at someone's face and seeing if it matches the passport photo isn't all of it, a lot of minor detail is included so that you have to pay attention carefully such as expiry date on the passport and region they are from etc. Don't worry, you get a warnings if you get it wrong but any more than 2 mistakes and you get fined.
As you progress through the story, it's gets more challenging and there is more specific requirements thrown at you such as workers have to present a valid work permit and certain documents are needed.
When you finish work, you get your pay and you have to feed your family, pay for heating and if your family is ill; medicine.
The worst part is to make wise decisions, such as sacrificing heating for your sons medicine, if you don't pay for the medicine, your family member might die and thats pretty depressing since your salary is quite low.
Although it might sound boring, there is an actual storyline to it, some events happen and your choice of actions might change the story a bit. You'll be glad that everyone you meet are different.
Also, you can get some grumpy people who can ♥♥♥♥ you off or you can get people who are desperate to migrate because of war and they beg you to let them in even though they don't have a passport. Decision making is pretty heavy in this game.
Overall, its interesting and fun game. I recommend it to those who have some time to kill and those who want pursue a border control career ;)

reviewText:
Short Review
Narrative: Focuses on role-playing
Gameplay: Time Rush Match the Picture" Point-and-Click
Score: 8/10
Recommended: Yes
Recommended buying point: Any discount of 50% or above
Recommended for: People who don't care about a game's length and more focused on the intensity of an experience it can give

Detailed Review
The Narrative
Story:
You are the husband to a family of five
date: including you. You have been selected to work as an immigration officer in the border of the country. Basically
recommended: you are the paperwork inspector of the eastern side of the infamous Checkpoint Charlie[en.wikipedia.org].\n\nAnd that's it. You get a few snips of the immigrants' lives and story
hoursPlayed: and there is indeed a "larger" storyline that somewhat follows the historical Checkpoint Charlie
voteText: but the core focus of the story is you and your decisions. You have the greatest agency in the entire game: You get to decide the fate of all sorts of people and even that of the country itself! All through a bunch of bureacracy decisions. Of course
helpfulPercent: you need to remember that your decisions
votesHelpful: ill-informed as it can be
votesTotal: also decides the fate of you and your family too. Rather than direct storytelling
votesFunny: the game puts a strong focus on storytelling through role-play.\n\nIf there is one weakness with the story
commentsCount: however
column16: is that some of the puzzles can be hard that it will lead you into searching for guides to solve them (an adventure game trademark
column17: really) which would really break immersion in the game and story. The moment you stop making on-the-spot from-the-heart decisions with the scant information available and think of getting a certain achievement or ending
column18:
at that moment the game really lose its grip on you.

Character:
There isn't much of a characterization in here. As a character
column19: the main character is 100% defined by your actions. You have a family
column20: but they don't show up in the game - they barely even do anything other than being a bunch of mouth for you to keep warm
column21: feed
column22: and stay healthy - keep the alive as having all of them killed nets you a gameover. Some of the immigrants shows a certain characterization
column23: but they are basically stranger which you only see for a few moments - as they are to you both in-character and meta-wise. The closest you have to legitimate characters are your co-workers.\n\nMost of the characters are just blank canvas for you to paint one - one person might think of one character as a jerk the other might think that he's not really a jerk. The focus in this game is in the role-play
column24: there is little characterization so you fill in the blanks with what you think of them. Provided that you play this game completely honestly (which I recommend you doing until you reach Day 32/end-game once) then it can say a lot of interesting things about you. Apparently
column25: I'm someone who can bend some rules and go against some moral and ethic codes so long as it isn't too big or if I need it.\n\nIt is a rather interesting experience
column26:
and what makes this game really strong.

The Gameplay
Mechanics:
The core mechanics of the game is basically similar to "Find what's different with the pictures" type of games. And easy comparison would be the Ace Attorney series of game
column27: except this one is much more minimalistic in its storytelling
column29: and less absurd or "anime-ish" but more grounded in reality.\n\nYou are presented with a bunch of documents
column30: you need to find what's wrong with it
column31: and match it with the rules or the other data that acts as a reference for how they are wrong. You then need to find if the discrepancies were simply outdated data or if the documents really are invalid. If it was all cleared and there's nothing wrong with the document
column34: you can either deny them or detain them (the latter gives a small bonus). At the end of the day
column35: you can choose if you want to feed your family and keep them warm or not
column36: as well as whether or not to give them medicine if they are sick. You can upgrade the booth for some shortcut commands and you can move to a more expensive appartment at certain days (which does nothing except for getting one achievement). Other than the rents and fines
column37: the bills are opt-out while the upgrades are opt-in.\n\nThe game started rather difficult as there is a lack of tutorial - which admittedly does fit the image of the fictional country in that they demand nothing but the best from their workers. The game asks you to be constantly vigil and have a good memory about the rules. If you do not
column38: then you might miss something that makes you get a warning from your superior or alternatively takes too long a time inspecting one immigrant meaning less immigrant processed and thus less money for you and your family. In a way
column39: the core gameplay revolves around weighting your choices. Whether to rush the inspection out or to take your time
column40: whether to be merciless or be nice
column41: whether to accept bribes or not. The game focuses on these small moments and what it says about you. The gameplay mechanics are really just a vehicle for the role-playing part of the game
column42: which is the main meat of the game.\n\nOverall
column43: it's not really fun - and I'm sure it's not intended to be fun or at least not in the traditional way of fun - but it's good at what it's trying to do and it didn't overstay its welcome (you can finish this game in a single weekend
column44: provided that you are good at it and know what you are doing). Although it is very annoying that many of the achievements are hidden and can be very hard to find unless you search a guide or the wiki (which as I said
column45:
can really break immersion in the game).

Optimization:
I was honestly surprised and floored by how light this game is. I would have thought that it would take a few hundreds megabyte
column46: but then I saw that it only took about 50MB when I was downloading the game! And I have a rather old computer and to my surprise
column47:
it ran smoothly despite how I was opening a bunch of Chrome tabs and Notepad++ (with five open documents in it). My guess is that this is because of the very traditional art-style and how a lot of its contents are procedurally generated except for some few scripted encounters and dialogues in the game.

The Aesthetics
Graphics:
The graphics is very traditional - it wouldn't be out-of-place in the NES console. In terms of fidelity
column48: it's pretty high in fidelity in spite of its look
column49: and it could clearly show everything that is needed. The art style was rather drab
column50: but it fits the tone and theme of the game
column51: as well as that of the setting. If there is one thing I have to criticize out of the graphic is that the in-game photo and the game's sprite can often looks rather different
column52:
leading to some confused moments. Not much to say other than that - it does its job and that's that.

Sound:
There isn't much to say about the sound department. It has about two or so music and about a dozen or so of SFX
column53: and that they do the jobs they needed to do. The music sets the mood pretty nicely but is otherwise not notable
column54: especially since during the main segment of the game they do not have any music at all (the music are only on the main menu and ending
column56: this is a very good game not in the gameplay but because of how immersive and bleak in can be. Is it worth your money? Well

reviewText:
10/10

Papers, Please is a game that can never be matched, purely by the perfect way this game was executed. You are an immigration inspector at the border town of Grestin. Your goal is simple; do your job correctly, get the money, and keep you and your family alive. But no, it is not this simple. You are the person that changes peoples lives entirely. To allow an individual into the country is completely your choice; a power that should not be given to a single person.

For a game with such a simple as well as unique concept, Papers, Please showed just how in-depth something so simple can go. From any person's perspective, it's a simple process: Accept. Deny. Accept. Deny. However, Something that simple is something that you cannot afford in Papers, Please. Passports, Entry Permits, Identity Supplements; all documents that each person must present to you; the inspector. Your duty is to correctly accept and deny immigrants into the country, (who may very well be terrorists, smugglers, and murderers,) in the country of Arstotzka.

What makes Papers, Please the brilliant game that it is lies in every fiber of its design. From the art style to the dialogue., this game will present new ideals into your mind, making you wonder what the true right or wrong thing to is. Papers, Please will make you want to keep your job more than any real world job ever will, that is a given fact. Getting penalized by the Ministry of Admission for incorrectly allowing people into Arstotzka will fill every inch of your body with paranoia. Even as you skim down someone's passport you will feel a small pinch in the back of your head, worrying that you checked something wrong. Being thorough means everything in this game, in the booth or at your Class 8 Apartment.

Papers, Please is a game that you have never seen or played before. With perfect atmosphere, story, and dialogue, this game has quickly made its way to my favorite games list. For the small price of only 10 credits, this game is less expensive than your son's birthday present! Buy it already!

Glory to Arstotzka. Back to work.

This is certainly not a review about the game itself. We ALL know how great it is.

reviewText: HIGHLY recommend this game. Essentially, in this game you play as a border agent who has to examine passports and other official documentation to determine whether a person is allowed entry into your country or not. The game starts off relatively easy and slowly progresses into a more complicated game as you progress. If you mess up, you'll be deducted pay at the end of the work day and your family will undoubtedly suffer as a result. While it sounds rather tedious and repetitive, it does suck you in. Before you know, you've wasted 6 hours trying to provide for your family while watching out for illegals.

reviewText: Unbelievably grim, sad, depressing, almost frustrating game. The world you live in has real stories, your decisions will have irreversible consequences, not only to the people you decide upon, but your own consience. Should you take care of your sister's daughter after your sister death, when your own child have no food for 3 days now? Should you let a wife of a just passed-through traveller, to enter when her papers are not correct, knowing that any penalty can cause you to have no money to pay for heat and your own wife is sick at home? Even your desk does not have enough space to put on all the papers that you need to check...\nA magnficent game, one of the few games that can really TEACH something to you and your kids, how real life can be sometimes, and at the same time, enjoyable with interesting twists in the storyline that makes every decision you make count until the end. It is so amazing that this simple but well-polished game was developed by a single indie developer.

reviewText: This is a very interesting game. The depressive world and story mixed with that intense music, a game i've never played before. It's very difficult and challenging, it requires all your concentration to not miss a tiny detail on any of the given papers; this game is for open-minded people who like very challenging, brain straining games. I really enjoyed the flow of the game, and loved the story changing characters, which appear ever so often, as well as all the other little details put in it. While intensly working on checking data from the papers, you always have to be ready for a terrorist attack or some other event which may come unexpected. I also especially like the moral choices (which do not have influence on the story), for example, will you accept the wife to get to her husband even though she doesnt't have correct data? Will you accept bribes for people with not enough money to get the needed papers? Then there are bigger decisions that may change the complete story of the game, which I will not give an example for, because they might contain big spoilers.\n\nThis game is definitely worth checking out, if you don't want to buy it, you might as well check out some videos on the web.

reviewText:
'Papers, Please' is a round based inspection game, where you play as immigration inspector.

Desc:
You play as immigration inspector to earn the livelihood for your family. At the end of each round you will get your daily salary - if your daily salary is too low and your reserves are too low, then you have to option whether your family will get no food and/or no heating. Your salary will get lowered, when you do mistakes during your inspection and you let somebody past who is not authorized to cross the border. Your family will get sick and yes; they will die, when you do to much mistakes at your work. Mistakes means, that you haven't asked the immigrant why his passport says that he is female but he looks male or you haven't followed the order that immigrants from a certain country won't be past, because of threat of terrorism. After certain days and enough money you can upgrade your booth to work more efficient. Over the time there will be scripted events where you have to make moral decisions. These decisions will influence the story. The final goal is to help or to infiltrate the country you are working for - and yes; it has multiple ends! ^^

Pros:
+ nice artwork
+ music and sound fit to the artwork
+ multiple ends
+ great game concept
+ rising level of difficulty
+ moral decisions which have effects
+ replayability

Cons:
- a bit hard at the beginning - you have to train! (a selectable level of difficulty would be great)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because the overall package is just right.

9/10

reviewText: This is probably my favorite game that I purchased during the recent huge sale. I've already completed the game twice but gotten a different ending each time (there are 20!), and I will definitely play it more. It's just totally weird that I am having so much fun with this... You're literally processing documents. This idea sounds terrible on paper (ha). However, it's actually really, really engaging and fun to play. The game is exceptionally immersive and completely different from anything that I have ever played before. You get tied up in these little stories with the people that come to your window, and often you feel a tinge of guilt as you turn away someone from the checkpoint when they tell you how you've doomed them. The atmosphere is extremely oppressive; the devs did a GREAT job of sucking the player into the world. The game does a great job of piling more tasks you have to complete with each level, and the constantly-ticking clock pushes you to cut corners. This game just has something about it that draws me back over and over. Highly recommended if you desire something unusual.

reviewText:
While the first glimpse says to a store-wanderer ''boring, boring, boring'', this idea is completely false. Papers, Please is the complete opposite of boring.

Taking place in a fictional semi-corrupt semi-just-want-MIA-members-kept-in-place country named Arstotzka, you play as a border control agent, accepting or denying job-seekers, immigrants and criminals. While this game's first few hours/minutes (depending on how quick your fingers are and how long it takes to strain them dragging documents around your messy desk) are quite dull, the people I saw in just that little amount of gameplay made me rage, laugh and stare. This is a brilliant attribute as it jolts the brain and your emotions to a flying start. Time to time the game gets harder and more time-consuming, but still follows the same laugh-rage experience. It also displays attributes of a shooter - you will sometimes see a terrorist attack and have the power to stop one at your protagonist's twiddling fingers.

It also gives you opinions and puzzles (including the bomb some idiot thought would kill off an inspector and all the guards surrounding him), like managing your expenses and doing whatever it takes to not be arrested for giving a single document to the police. While this isn't too frequent it still makes you happy there's a change in the game and you have some freedom.

Graphics-wise the game is pixellated, but looks lovely at the same time. This style fits the time the game was set, as I just thought, considering it is set in the 80s, a time when 8-bits were first introduced. It also displays musical talent, and the theme makes me want to go on a march in synchronization with it.

So, overall, I'd say Papers, Please, from such a simple idea, turns out to be one of my favourite games of all time, and I congratulate Dukope for making such a brilliant game.
10/10. Glory to Arstotzka.

Absolutely an amazing title, very original as far as I am concerned.

You play a person that decides who and who can not get into your country. Rules changes every day as to who can get in, making it easier and easier everyday to miss stuff, so you better pay attention, the game requires your attention if you don't want to go in debt.

You're faced with many moral decisions.

Do you want to ignore the rules and accept him into the country and risk going in debt or do you want to follow the rules of Arstotzka and deny him?

Glory to Arstotzka.

9/10, must buy.

reviewText:
Papers, Please was first introduced to me in Alpha, and it was already great. I followed it through development and into Steam, where it got bigger and better.

The constant being on-edge, management, strategy and difficulties you face are balanced by a wonderful simplistic art style and great soundtrack. The interface is perhaps a little counter-intuitive at points for me, but that's really my only problem with it. Given the number of endings, its replay value is immense. Even today after [insert large number here] hours of gameplay, I'm finding new things to do, new things I like doing in the game.

The best part is the waiting, which makes no sense without context. After you approve an applicant, there's the little tense wait to see if you got a citation. You begin to hate the little *clickity click* sound of the citation appearing, and makes you get angry at the system. You want revenge, and EZIC are there to help. Personally, I've always gone against EZIC, but the game adapts to your playstyle, once you adapt to it.

The best kind of game is one that impacts upon the player and vice versa. Papers, Please is definitely in that category.

reviewText: Who would have thought that being a border checkpoint inspector for a communist country would make for a compelling game? Papers, Please pulls it off with aplomb, featuring enough ambiguous moral choices and multiple endings to warrant several playthroughs. The gameplay consists primarily of verifying the accuracy and authenticity of documentation, though the choice of whether or not to let someone through rests entirely with you. Sometimes letting someone through regardless of paperwork seems like the right thing to do but when you have bills to pay, morality can often take a backseat. Communist border checkpoint inspectors gotta eat!\n\nPapers, Please is definitely worth a try, even if you find the premise unappealing. You may just be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Papers, Please. Glory To Arstotzka's Boring Yet Compelling JobGenre: Point & Click Puzzle Simulation
Developed & Published by: 3909
Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux.
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
You are a border guard of Arstotzka, a fictional government that has forced you into your current job. Your job, I might add, is to get as many people processed through the border as quickly as you can. The more people you process correctly, the more money you earn for the day. However, the job is made difficult with forged documentation, lists of rules you must make sure everyone has adhered to and an ever-increasing pile of paperwork to sift through. As you make mistakes, it costs money and could potentially get yourself jailed if you’re that terrible at your job. Your family has demands as well and the cost of living will go up, demanding that you work harder at processing more people through the gate every passing day.

Papers, Please isn’t a pleasant stroll through the park. The work you’re doing is tedious and dull. Every new face a source of income and potential frustration. Inspections taking progressively longer as you become more paranoid of your fallibility. Let one guy through and he’s fine. Let the next woman through, whose paperwork seems legitimate, only to get instantly penalized as her documentation was expired. Then I begin checking documentation to make sure it isn’t expired only to get penalized for letting a criminal through. Curses! Then you deny the next person because something seems missing with his documentatio--oops, nope, he was completely fine. I just denied a man from seeing his wife. Now I have to be extra-careful with the next guy, which takes me over an hour of in-game time just to realize that his paperwork completely checks out. Damnit it all! I need to move faster. The Next person has concealed explosives but I forget to check his weight so he gets through and blows up the guards. The day is abruptly over. My income cut short, my family starves. I curse my inadequacy.

Papers Please is a constant balance of fact-checking, observation and being as quick as possible with some of the most intentionally-clunky tools a border guard could possess. Each tool taking their own portion of precious time to make sure the documentation is or isn’t correct. Even if you know that person’s paperwork is wrong, you have to verify it with the in-game data checker, interrogate the person to be sure you’re correct and then and only then, can you call for the guards. All the while, the clock ticks on insidiously. Waiting to instantly call you out on that inevitable mistake you’ll make.

Game Modes
There are two main game modes, story and endless. Story is a 31 day campaign with branching story paths based on the decisions you make. Whether it’s support for the rising rebellion against Arstotzka, support of the old government, getting caught doing illegal activities or adverse conditions affecting your family, ultimately remains up to you. The story is excellently paced and down to earth with each decision you make being personable. While some decisions may seem black and white at first, you may find out later that events didn’t play out as you expected. The story more or less gives reason for why you’re there and how your decisions affect what ultimately ends up happening. To you, the government or other factions at work. While many that try to cross the border are procedural generated, in the story mode there are some that aren’t. These crafted characters can be depressing, heart wrenching or sometimes amusing. This isn’t a simulation of a border guard’s job but it’s the closest game to being one while remaining entertaining for many.

Endless gives you three ways to play with four levels of difficulty. There’s a timed mode where you process as many travelers in 10 minutes as possible. Perfection which has you going as long as you can until you make a mistake. Finally, there’s Endurance which has you playing until the score balances out from your mistakes. These simply give you a way to enjoy the game after the story and are a nice, simple addition.

PC Settings
Unsurprisingly basic settings, but usable for a 2D game. You have fullscreen, windowed mode and software rendering in case your hardware isn’t good enough. There’s a nudity on/off switch as well as an “Easy Mode” which gives you 20 credits every day. Separate volume sliders exist as well. However, there’s only one very catchy song that’s played in the main menu. The graphic style is, what I would consider, an oppressive & depressing pixelart. It looks great despite it not being a very colorful title.

Final Thoughts
Papers Please is one of my favorite games of 2013. It keeps the dry experience of a border guard but still has depressing stories to tell. The pixelart and dreary atmosphere combine with the constant & insidious pressure to make for a very compelling experience. It’s a game that I shouldn’t find enjoyable but yet I do. Its an odd game that says something not only through words but through the game’s mechanics as well.

Read the Review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText: Papers, Please is an incredible game. It happens to be one of my favourites on Steam. The gameplay is always fun and engaging and is also rather addictive. The great thing about this game is that there is lots of replayability. The scenarios are always different, meaning that you will always be challenged, which is a great thing. reviewText:
While the first glimpse says to a store-wanderer ''boring, boring, boring'', this idea is completely false. Papers, Please is the complete opposite of boring.

Taking place in a fictional semi-corrupt semi-just-want-MIA-members-kept-in-place country named Arstotzka, you play as a border control agent, accepting or denying job-seekers, immigrants and criminals. While this game's first few hours/minutes (depending on how quick your fingers are and how long it takes to strain them dragging documents around your messy desk) are quite dull, the people I saw in just that little amount of gameplay made me rage, laugh and stare. This is a brilliant attribute as it jolts the brain and your emotions to a flying start. Time to time the game gets harder and more time-consuming, but still follows the same laugh-rage experience. It also displays attributes of a shooter - you will sometimes see a terrorist attack and have the power to stop one at your protagonist's twiddling fingers.

It also gives you opinions and puzzles (including the bomb some idiot thought would kill off an inspector and all the guards surrounding him), like managing your expenses and doing whatever it takes to not be arrested for giving a single document to the police. While this isn't too frequent it still makes you happy there's a change in the game and you have some freedom.

Graphics-wise the game is pixellated, but looks lovely at the same time. This style fits the time the game was set, as I just thought, considering it is set in the 80s, a time when 8-bits were first introduced. It also displays musical talent, and the theme makes me want to go on a march in synchronization with it.

So, overall, I'd say Papers, Please, from such a simple idea, turns out to be one of my favourite games of all time, and I congratulate Dukope for making such a brilliant game.
10/10. Glory to Arstotzka.

reviewText: This is probably my favorite game that I purchased during the recent huge sale. I've already completed the game twice but gotten a different ending each time (there are 20!), and I will definitely play it more. It's just totally weird that I am having so much fun with this... You're literally processing documents. This idea sounds terrible on paper (ha). However, it's actually really, really engaging and fun to play. The game is exceptionally immersive and completely different from anything that I have ever played before. You get tied up in these little stories with the people that come to your window, and often you feel a tinge of guilt as you turn away someone from the checkpoint when they tell you how you've doomed them. The atmosphere is extremely oppressive; the devs did a GREAT job of sucking the player into the world. The game does a great job of piling more tasks you have to complete with each level, and the constantly-ticking clock pushes you to cut corners. This game just has something about it that draws me back over and over. Highly recommended if you desire something unusual.

reviewText:
'Papers, Please' is a round based inspection game, where you play as immigration inspector.

Desc:
You play as immigration inspector to earn the livelihood for your family. At the end of each round you will get your daily salary - if your daily salary is too low and your reserves are too low, then you have to option whether your family will get no food and/or no heating. Your salary will get lowered, when you do mistakes during your inspection and you let somebody past who is not authorized to cross the border. Your family will get sick and yes; they will die, when you do to much mistakes at your work. Mistakes means, that you haven't asked the immigrant why his passport says that he is female but he looks male or you haven't followed the order that immigrants from a certain country won't be past, because of threat of terrorism. After certain days and enough money you can upgrade your booth to work more efficient. Over the time there will be scripted events where you have to make moral decisions. These decisions will influence the story. The final goal is to help or to infiltrate the country you are working for - and yes; it has multiple ends! ^^

Pros:
+ nice artwork
+ music and sound fit to the artwork
+ multiple ends
+ great game concept
+ rising level of difficulty
+ moral decisions which have effects
+ replayability

Cons:
- a bit hard at the beginning - you have to train! (a selectable level of difficulty would be great)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because the overall package is just right.

9/10

reviewText: It is a dark age of communism.  Your country has just ended hostilities with its neighbor and are now allowing travel into the country.  You are in control at the Berl...I mean Grestin Wall.  Not by choice, but by threat of death if you are not able to provide for your family or if you even inadvertantly perform the tiniest act that may be traitorous.  Slight missteps result in citations that take away what little money you are paid to support your family.  Enjoy the great communist pasttime of:  Food or Heat?  Will your family starve or freeze?  All up to you in this dystopian masterpiece that is a lot better than I have described.  Yet it is exactly as I described it, but for some reason it is one of the most addictive games I've played in awhile; fair warning, it can be repetive and menial and I have some minor OCD which could be why I enjoyed it.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Papers, Please. Glory To Arstotzka's Boring Yet Compelling JobGenre: Point & Click Puzzle Simulation
Developed & Published by: 3909
Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux.
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
You are a border guard of Arstotzka, a fictional government that has forced you into your current job. Your job, I might add, is to get as many people processed through the border as quickly as you can. The more people you process correctly, the more money you earn for the day. However, the job is made difficult with forged documentation, lists of rules you must make sure everyone has adhered to and an ever-increasing pile of paperwork to sift through. As you make mistakes, it costs money and could potentially get yourself jailed if you’re that terrible at your job. Your family has demands as well and the cost of living will go up, demanding that you work harder at processing more people through the gate every passing day.

Papers, Please isn’t a pleasant stroll through the park. The work you’re doing is tedious and dull. Every new face a source of income and potential frustration. Inspections taking progressively longer as you become more paranoid of your fallibility. Let one guy through and he’s fine. Let the next woman through, whose paperwork seems legitimate, only to get instantly penalized as her documentation was expired. Then I begin checking documentation to make sure it isn’t expired only to get penalized for letting a criminal through. Curses! Then you deny the next person because something seems missing with his documentatio--oops, nope, he was completely fine. I just denied a man from seeing his wife. Now I have to be extra-careful with the next guy, which takes me over an hour of in-game time just to realize that his paperwork completely checks out. Damnit it all! I need to move faster. The Next person has concealed explosives but I forget to check his weight so he gets through and blows up the guards. The day is abruptly over. My income cut short, my family starves. I curse my inadequacy.

Papers Please is a constant balance of fact-checking, observation and being as quick as possible with some of the most intentionally-clunky tools a border guard could possess. Each tool taking their own portion of precious time to make sure the documentation is or isn’t correct. Even if you know that person’s paperwork is wrong, you have to verify it with the in-game data checker, interrogate the person to be sure you’re correct and then and only then, can you call for the guards. All the while, the clock ticks on insidiously. Waiting to instantly call you out on that inevitable mistake you’ll make.

Game Modes
There are two main game modes, story and endless. Story is a 31 day campaign with branching story paths based on the decisions you make. Whether it’s support for the rising rebellion against Arstotzka, support of the old government, getting caught doing illegal activities or adverse conditions affecting your family, ultimately remains up to you. The story is excellently paced and down to earth with each decision you make being personable. While some decisions may seem black and white at first, you may find out later that events didn’t play out as you expected. The story more or less gives reason for why you’re there and how your decisions affect what ultimately ends up happening. To you, the government or other factions at work. While many that try to cross the border are procedural generated, in the story mode there are some that aren’t. These crafted characters can be depressing, heart wrenching or sometimes amusing. This isn’t a simulation of a border guard’s job but it’s the closest game to being one while remaining entertaining for many.

Endless gives you three ways to play with four levels of difficulty. There’s a timed mode where you process as many travelers in 10 minutes as possible. Perfection which has you going as long as you can until you make a mistake. Finally, there’s Endurance which has you playing until the score balances out from your mistakes. These simply give you a way to enjoy the game after the story and are a nice, simple addition.

PC Settings
Unsurprisingly basic settings, but usable for a 2D game. You have fullscreen, windowed mode and software rendering in case your hardware isn’t good enough. There’s a nudity on/off switch as well as an “Easy Mode” which gives you 20 credits every day. Separate volume sliders exist as well. However, there’s only one very catchy song that’s played in the main menu. The graphic style is, what I would consider, an oppressive & depressing pixelart. It looks great despite it not being a very colorful title.

Final Thoughts
Papers Please is one of my favorite games of 2013. It keeps the dry experience of a border guard but still has depressing stories to tell. The pixelart and dreary atmosphere combine with the constant & insidious pressure to make for a very compelling experience. It’s a game that I shouldn’t find enjoyable but yet I do. Its an odd game that says something not only through words but through the game’s mechanics as well.

Read the Review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText: Very polite title, which I appreciate. Most other games are so aggressively named, but Papers Please has the decency to ask nicely. Especially good given the nature of the game and its depiction of a totalitarian police state with strict and unwavering border control regulations. Juxtaposition is a great word to play in Scrabble if you can get your hands on an X or a Blank. Just wait until somebody writes position" and then add the "juxta" with the biggest look of smugness you can muster. That's my favourite part of Scrabble. My favourite part of this game though is the achievement you can get for being arrested for being too honest. That made me happy."

A indy game to sink your teeth into. Although the set-up of the game is very simple, you basically see one screen all game, the story will take you on a emotional journey. You are a government worker at the border and you will have to check all the people who want to go through your border.

reviewText:
I picked up this game a year ago, needing a small game to tide me over since I couldn't really get involved in big immersive RPGs. I was extremely surprized with that I got.

I had heard Papers Please is a good game but I didn't expect the kind of addiciton that makes you play it for 7 hours straight. It's hard to pin point what really achieves this level of addiction. But it's probably a combination of genuine challenge, an interesting story line and essentially thousands of moral choice elements for 20 possible endings.

Don't snub it, it's a fantastic game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Frankly, this game is masterfully done. The idea is original, the graphics fit the claustrophobic and choking atmosphere, the music enhances the idea of a smothering government regime in which the player finds himself as both citizen and employee, and the stories told through the window of your booth are engaging and develop themselves with intrigue and secrecy. It's hard to find where this game could be improved. It's something that works so well as a game, and as an educational experience that it could almost be used in a teaching environment. The idea that a citizen of this government would be placed into the position they are, allowing or denying various people access to their country, seeing the amount of paperwork involved, watching the rules and regulations pile up and change over the course of time leading to frustration, being faced with the moral dilemmas asked of them, and deciding how to handle their allegiance to country versus their conscious and compassion for other human beings is something that truly isn't captured as well as it is here with Papers, Please.

I will say that the game is so well done, that it actually feels like work after awhile, which cuts into the fun factor, though it enchances the simulation aspect. It's almost hard to qualify it into a genre. The mechanics are crisp and clean, they build on themselves day after day, slowly increasing the difficulty by usually adding one or two additional rules, and eventually the player will find that they are totally immersed in the experience. It does feel like work after awhile though, so some players may actually be glad to 'punch out' after an hour or two of game play.

This is a game that has  left me thinking about it long after I exit the program. It's something that reaches a state where it's actually more than a game, it's a slice of actual human life.

This falls into the same category as This War of Mine in that it's an important game, and one that people should play with more in mind that just entertainment. Excellent, excellent purchase.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Who would have thought that being a border checkpoint inspector for a communist country would make for a compelling game? Papers, Please pulls it off with aplomb, featuring enough ambiguous moral choices and multiple endings to warrant several playthroughs. The gameplay consists primarily of verifying the accuracy and authenticity of documentation, though the choice of whether or not to let someone through rests entirely with you. Sometimes letting someone through regardless of paperwork seems like the right thing to do but when you have bills to pay, morality can often take a backseat. Communist border checkpoint inspectors gotta eat!\n\nPapers, Please is definitely worth a try, even if you find the premise unappealing. You may just be pleasantly surprised.

Final Thoughts
Papers Please is one of my favorite games of 2013. It keeps the dry experience of a border guard but still has depressing stories to tell. The pixelart and dreary atmosphere combine with the constant & insidious pressure to make for a very compelling experience. It’s a game that I shouldn’t find enjoyable but yet I do. Its an odd game that says something not only through words but through the game’s mechanics as well.

Read the Review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText:
Immigration inspector simulator

'Papers, Please' is a point and click, puzzle game developed by 3909.

There isn't much story in the game. You basically play as a immigration inspector who manages who get into the country of Azoska (as well as look after your family). Certain events are detailed via text boxes or in the newspaper. There a over ten endings in the game, which occur based on player action.

Gameplay is exceptional. You need to check the credentials of people who are entering the country and only let in people who meet the laws. This includes checking height, photo, passports, work visa etc. to find any discrepencies. If there are no problems you let them through, else you have to deny access into the country.  At each level, you only have a limited amount of time to work and earn money. Therefore you have to arrange where each piece of document you are given goes (either on the desk or counter) so you can efficiently check and hand those papers back as quickly as possible in order get the next visitor and hence more money. Each person you let in earns you ten dollars, while at the same time any mistakes you make (after the first one) will deduct money from you. Money is used at the end of the level to pay for your family's needs e.g. food and rent. Failure to earn enough money will mean that your family members start dieing off. Your moraility will also be tested in the game with various decisions such as whether to accept bribes, detain people to get more money, whether to let a grieving mother through etc. Basically you have to manage your job, family and morales during the game.

There is minimal audio in the game. Alarms and paper sound as they should. People speak via text boxes and some of their dialogue are quite humorous.

Graphics aren't that detaile, but they do a good job at setting a surpressive atmosphere.

If you want to have unique, somewhat-funny point and click game, this game won't dissapoint.

reviewText:
Short Review
Narrative: Focuses on role-playing
Gameplay: Time Rush Match the Picture" Point-and-Click
Score: 8/10
Recommended: Yes
Recommended buying point: Any discount of 50% or above
Recommended for: People who don't care about a game's length and more focused on the intensity of an experience it can give

Detailed Review
The Narrative
Story:
You are the husband to a family of five
date: including you. You have been selected to work as an immigration officer in the border of the country. Basically
recommended: you are the paperwork inspector of the eastern side of the infamous Checkpoint Charlie[en.wikipedia.org].\n\nAnd that's it. You get a few snips of the immigrants' lives and story
hoursPlayed: and there is indeed a "larger" storyline that somewhat follows the historical Checkpoint Charlie
voteText: but the core focus of the story is you and your decisions. You have the greatest agency in the entire game: You get to decide the fate of all sorts of people and even that of the country itself! All through a bunch of bureacracy decisions. Of course
helpfulPercent: you need to remember that your decisions
votesHelpful: ill-informed as it can be

commentsCount: however

column18:
at that moment the game really lose its grip on you.

Character:
There isn't much of a characterization in here. As a character
column19: the main character is 100% defined by your actions. You have a family

column21: feed
column22: and stay healthy - keep the alive as having all of them killed nets you a gameover. Some of the immigrants shows a certain characterization
column23: but they are basically stranger which you only see for a few moments - as they are to you both in-character and meta-wise. The closest you have to legitimate characters are your co-workers.\n\nMost of the characters are just blank canvas for you to paint one - one person might think of one character as a jerk the other might think that he's not really a jerk. The focus in this game is in the role-play
column24: there is little characterization so you fill in the blanks with what you think of them. Provided that you play this game completely honestly (which I recommend you doing until you reach Day 32/end-game once) then it can say a lot of interesting things about you. Apparently
column25: I'm someone who can bend some rules and go against some moral and ethic codes so long as it isn't too big or if I need it.\n\nIt is a rather interesting experience
column26:
and what makes this game really strong.

The Gameplay
Mechanics:
The core mechanics of the game is basically similar to "Find what's different with the pictures" type of games. And easy comparison would be the Ace Attorney series of game
column27: except this one is much more minimalistic in its storytelling
column29: and less absurd or "anime-ish" but more grounded in reality.\n\nYou are presented with a bunch of documents
column30: you need to find what's wrong with it

column37: the bills are opt-out while the upgrades are opt-in.\n\nThe game started rather difficult as there is a lack of tutorial - which admittedly does fit the image of the fictional country in that they demand nothing but the best from their workers. The game asks you to be constantly vigil and have a good memory about the rules. If you do not

reviewText:
This is certainly not a review about the game itself. We ALL know how great it is.

I'm here to talk about the quality of its Linux port. I'm not surprised that an indie title has flawless support so far, compared to certain AAA titles I will not mention right now.

Everything works as you'd expect, display, input, audio... no major problems. There's just a rare issue with certain lines of text having a whole row of pixels chopped off, but it doesn't affect readability (if it happens on Windows too, then it's all ok).

PS: I like the fact on fullscreen it uses nearest neighbor interpolation and keeps pixels square. I'm kind of a sucker for that.

reviewText:
Quick Breakdown: A stellar game where you play as an inspector working at a border checkpoint between your communist country of Arstotzka, and the neighboring country Kolechia, which your country has just recently ended a 6 year war with.
Length: 2-4 hours (Main game), 8-10 (Completionists)
Score: 8.5/10

Full Review: Papers Please is a truly unique game. Admittedly, it’s a pretty tough sell. On paper, the game sounds like it’d be awful. Even when I purchased the game, I wasn’t really sold on it, but I took a chance on it based on the ravings from my friends, and the low sale price of $2.50. After playing the game, I’m glad I did. It’s worth getting at full price even, but this is Steam, we all wait for the sales, don’t we?

So why’s it a tough sell? Well, you play as an inspector at a border checkpoint. People give you their papers needed to enter, and you look over them and either let them enter your country,  deny them entry if their papers are not all in order, or even detain them if need be. Sound like fun? To me it didn’t, but maybe you can see the appeal there.

So why is it worth playing? Odd as it may be, that very task I talked about in the last paragraph actually is a lot of fun. But there’s further reason that is even more compelling. You work for the glorious country or Arstotzka, at the checkpoint the border town of Grestin. The half of Grestin belongs to the neighboring country of Kolechia, which Arstotzka has just ended a 6 year war with. Your border checkpoint has just opened because of this, and people are once again allowed to enter Arstotzka for the first time in 6 years. This setting, and the people it brings through your checkpoint, and the events it leads to, are the game’s biggest strengths. You’ll encounter natives trying to re-enter the country, foreigners who can finally come to Arstotzka to work or visit, or even just pass through. There will also be terrorists, who aim to harm your glorious country, and it is your duty to deny and even detain them.

The game’s story and dialogue are both well written. Your actions during the day (the gameplay portion, which we’ll get to in a moment) affect the story between days, and down the road. Both the one time characters passing through, and those who are recurring are interesting, and some even quite memorable. (I think everyone who’s played this game loves Jorji). The dialogue is quite good, and has plenty of memorable lines.

So what of the gameplay? It’s done in a single screen, divided into 3 portions. Roughly the top third of the screen is a top down view of the border checkpoint, the line, and the guards. This part isn’t used too often for gameplay. The bottom two thirds of the screen are divided as well, the left third presents a first person point of view from your place inside your border checkpoint. This is where applicants seeking entry to Arstotzka come in and give you your papers. The rest of the bottom portion of your screen is where you can look at said papers up close.

Now this is the part of the game that I think is the hardest part to sell someone on, but I’m going to try anyway. When the game starts, applicants give you a passport, and so long as they are a resident of Arstotzka with a valid passport, they may enter the country. You simply stamp all passports with either “approved” or “denied.”
At the end of the day you will be paid 5 credits for every person you correctly processed. The first two incorrectly processed applicants will earn you a citation with a warning and no payment, each error after that will also incur a penalty docking some of your pay. Citations are reset at the beginning of each day.

During this end of day phase you will also need to balance your finances, and decide if you have money to pay for heat in your apartment, or to purchase food for your family. If you’re not able to take care of them properly they can die. If they’re all dead, or if you run out of money entirely you’ll get a gamer over (there are other ways to get a game over, in total the game has 20 different endings). So it’s important to do your job well.

On day 2 things become more complicated, and foreigners may enter as well so long as their passport is valid. On each passport you have various things to check for, a valid issuing city, that their photo matches their physical appearance, and that it hasn’t yet expired.

As the days go on more documents and rules will be introduced. I won’t go over all of them, but you will also have documents for entry permits, work permits, and you’ll need to crosscheck the name and passport number -as well as other information- on these documents with what’s printed on their passport. Sometimes you’ll also need to fingerprint an applicant, or search them for weapons or contraband (can’t let the drug smugglers and terrorists in). You’ll need to go over the documents carefully, pointing out discrepancies, and even giving a proper reason for denial. On occasion you’ll need to detain some of the applicants instead of simply denying them entry.

That about covers the basics of the game, so let’s move on to the graphics. They’re done in a simple pixel style, they’re not anything fancy, but they are pleasant to look at, and they help set the dreary mood of the game.

And it is quite dreary working this sort of job in an oppressive country, barely making enough to care for your family and survive. The music is good, and helps compliments this mood, and so do the sound effects.

My main criticism of the game is levelled at trying to point out discrepancies. Now, it’s not that I have issue doing this, I enjoy it. No no, my issue is that while you know which rule is broken, it’s not always clear how to properly point this out. Once you do figure it out, it’s a non-issue the next time you must deny someone entry for the same reason, and it’s not an issue most of the time, but it happens occasionally, and there’s not really a good reason for it.
In the end though, Papers Please is a fantastic game. If you’ve not played it yet, hopefully I’ve been able to convince you to give it a go, if you’re on the fence though, I urge you to gamble on it anyway, wait for a sale even if you wish. Just make sure that you do play this game.

Glory to Arstotzka!

reviewText:
Do you like games that make you think?

Do you like games set in Soviet Russia?

If you answered Yes" to any of the above

reviewText:
Papers, Please manages to make what would seem like a midless task mean lots to the player, all while presenting new challenges and thrills throughout the game and managing to be terrifyingly immersive. This is the only game where poor controls can be described as intentional, and they are, to make the grinding task of passport-stamping intentionally tedious and frustrating. Even as a humble worker, you feel powerful as you stamp the papers of endless npcs, some of which contribute to the story. While it won't appeal to those gamers who want nothing but the finest gameplay, the aesthetic, story, message and overall tone of Papers, Please draws many to enjoy it. In fact, the strenuous task of paperwork shuffling can actually become fun and addicting to perfectionists like myself.

While short, there are 20 endings in the game, 3 of which are considered good". Obtaining my desired good ending is one of the most rewarding thigs I've experienced from a game.

10 dollars is a bit of a stretch for those who don't know what they're getting from this game
date: but I would reccomend it to absolutely anyone on sale."

reviewText:
Quick Breakdown: A stellar game where you play as an inspector working at a border checkpoint between your communist country of Arstotzka, and the neighboring country Kolechia, which your country has just recently ended a 6 year war with.
Length: 2-4 hours (Main game), 8-10 (Completionists)
Score: 8.5/10

Full Review: Papers Please is a truly unique game. Admittedly, it’s a pretty tough sell. On paper, the game sounds like it’d be awful. Even when I purchased the game, I wasn’t really sold on it, but I took a chance on it based on the ravings from my friends, and the low sale price of $2.50. After playing the game, I’m glad I did. It’s worth getting at full price even, but this is Steam, we all wait for the sales, don’t we?

So why’s it a tough sell? Well, you play as an inspector at a border checkpoint. People give you their papers needed to enter, and you look over them and either let them enter your country,  deny them entry if their papers are not all in order, or even detain them if need be. Sound like fun? To me it didn’t, but maybe you can see the appeal there.

So why is it worth playing? Odd as it may be, that very task I talked about in the last paragraph actually is a lot of fun. But there’s further reason that is even more compelling. You work for the glorious country or Arstotzka, at the checkpoint the border town of Grestin. The half of Grestin belongs to the neighboring country of Kolechia, which Arstotzka has just ended a 6 year war with. Your border checkpoint has just opened because of this, and people are once again allowed to enter Arstotzka for the first time in 6 years. This setting, and the people it brings through your checkpoint, and the events it leads to, are the game’s biggest strengths. You’ll encounter natives trying to re-enter the country, foreigners who can finally come to Arstotzka to work or visit, or even just pass through. There will also be terrorists, who aim to harm your glorious country, and it is your duty to deny and even detain them.

The game’s story and dialogue are both well written. Your actions during the day (the gameplay portion, which we’ll get to in a moment) affect the story between days, and down the road. Both the one time characters passing through, and those who are recurring are interesting, and some even quite memorable. (I think everyone who’s played this game loves Jorji). The dialogue is quite good, and has plenty of memorable lines.

So what of the gameplay? It’s done in a single screen, divided into 3 portions. Roughly the top third of the screen is a top down view of the border checkpoint, the line, and the guards. This part isn’t used too often for gameplay. The bottom two thirds of the screen are divided as well, the left third presents a first person point of view from your place inside your border checkpoint. This is where applicants seeking entry to Arstotzka come in and give you your papers. The rest of the bottom portion of your screen is where you can look at said papers up close.

Now this is the part of the game that I think is the hardest part to sell someone on, but I’m going to try anyway. When the game starts, applicants give you a passport, and so long as they are a resident of Arstotzka with a valid passport, they may enter the country. You simply stamp all passports with either “approved” or “denied.”
At the end of the day you will be paid 5 credits for every person you correctly processed. The first two incorrectly processed applicants will earn you a citation with a warning and no payment, each error after that will also incur a penalty docking some of your pay. Citations are reset at the beginning of each day.

During this end of day phase you will also need to balance your finances, and decide if you have money to pay for heat in your apartment, or to purchase food for your family. If you’re not able to take care of them properly they can die. If they’re all dead, or if you run out of money entirely you’ll get a gamer over (there are other ways to get a game over, in total the game has 20 different endings). So it’s important to do your job well.

On day 2 things become more complicated, and foreigners may enter as well so long as their passport is valid. On each passport you have various things to check for, a valid issuing city, that their photo matches their physical appearance, and that it hasn’t yet expired.

As the days go on more documents and rules will be introduced. I won’t go over all of them, but you will also have documents for entry permits, work permits, and you’ll need to crosscheck the name and passport number -as well as other information- on these documents with what’s printed on their passport. Sometimes you’ll also need to fingerprint an applicant, or search them for weapons or contraband (can’t let the drug smugglers and terrorists in). You’ll need to go over the documents carefully, pointing out discrepancies, and even giving a proper reason for denial. On occasion you’ll need to detain some of the applicants instead of simply denying them entry.

That about covers the basics of the game, so let’s move on to the graphics. They’re done in a simple pixel style, they’re not anything fancy, but they are pleasant to look at, and they help set the dreary mood of the game.

And it is quite dreary working this sort of job in an oppressive country, barely making enough to care for your family and survive. The music is good, and helps compliments this mood, and so do the sound effects.

My main criticism of the game is levelled at trying to point out discrepancies. Now, it’s not that I have issue doing this, I enjoy it. No no, my issue is that while you know which rule is broken, it’s not always clear how to properly point this out. Once you do figure it out, it’s a non-issue the next time you must deny someone entry for the same reason, and it’s not an issue most of the time, but it happens occasionally, and there’s not really a good reason for it.
In the end though, Papers Please is a fantastic game. If you’ve not played it yet, hopefully I’ve been able to convince you to give it a go, if you’re on the fence though, I urge you to gamble on it anyway, wait for a sale even if you wish. Just make sure that you do play this game.

Glory to Arstotzka!

reviewText: After hearing about this game (I can't remember where from), I decided to take a chance and play it, and that choice was definitely a good one. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to try something new, and wants to do more on-the-spot thinking instead playing your average combat-filled games. The plot line is good, following a mock simulation of the Cold War Era and how foreign relations with the Soviet Union affected people. It does get frustrating at times  (I sometimes wanted to smash my computer), but it really helps your critical reading and fast-paced problem solving. If you're on the fence as to whether or not to buy this game, I say give it a shot, because it's such an original and interesting concept that you'll be missing out if you don't play it.

reviewText:
This is the kind of indie game that I really like... it's obviously low-budget, and the graphics, interface and sound are totally old school. Yet, it doesn't matter, as the game itself is pretty unique and interesting... maybe even addictive.

Basically, it's an exercise in concentration. Each day, your job as a passport-controller becomes more difficult. At first, there are like 2-3 things to watch out for. Each day, a new thing to observe and look out for is added, and so you need to remember more and more things to watch out for. Some of them don't come up for quite some time, but once you get too careless, you miss those things and fail.

Fortunately, you can mess up a few times each day without having to pay a fee from your measly pay. Then again, the more complaints you get, the worse it gets, as there also is some kind of inspector who will judge your efficiency every once in a while.

I recommend to write down the issueing cities from each region on a piece of paper... otherwise, you might lose quite some time checking every time.

I have played this for 5 hours so far, in two sessions, and I notice that it really can eat away at your ability to concentrate, so I think this is best played casually... do like half an hour at a time so you don't burn yourself out.

I really like the theme, as it DOES make you think a bit about how unfair the system in that country is, and you have to make some harsh decisions. There even are a few puzzles in there in the story-mode.

Kudos to the developer... this is a fun little game, and to me, the old school graphics don't matter at all, as the core of the game is very well thought out, and it's fun!

reviewText:
Papers, Please is one of those very pleasant, tiny surprises that comes along every now and again. And I do mean tiny: 30 megs tiny. That's four times the price of an iTunes HD episode for less than one-fifteenth the size, but believe me when I say that you'll spend more time on this game than you ever would watching any episode of any TV show.

The power of the game lies in its simple and complex art style and moral elements, respectively. Your position sees very little of any colour other than greys and blacks, probably reflecting that the morality that the game pushes you towards. Almost your money goes to rent, food and heat for your family at the end of each workday, and you get paid by how many people you process correctly. This would normally just serve to give the players incentive to pay attention and not ♥♥♥♥ up, but the game has the simple trick of any citizen just claiming what any citizen would. Maybe they want to get into the country to see their family or reunite with their significant other, and turning them away means breaking that. Of course, letting them through means you might not be able to afford heat this evening.

The game has problems, sure. If you're not the type for it, the morality system falls completely flat and you just don't care, because there's no real penalty for simply doing your job aside from citizens calling you an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in 16-bit text before disappearing forever. The booth upgrades aren't very helpful, and I can't say that this is the most thrilling game to play if you're playing on a stationary rig that can run many more exciting, if not as compelling, games. That being said, it is still surprisingly engaging for its size; I found myself able to play it (before I bought the Steam version) in class for sometimes hours at a time, just processing and processing over and over. And its size and almost non-existant graphical tax means that no matter your specs, you could run it.

In conclusion, it's more than worth recommending. The phrase Simple
date: yet elegant" is thrown around a lot but it really does find a place here
recommended: amongst the endless passports and tickets that will inevitably clutter your desk. If you're the type for it
hoursPlayed: pick it up anyway

reviewText:
Papers, Please is a prime example that a game does not need a big budget to be great.

Who would've though stamping papers in a border checkpoint box could be fun? The game has a very original concept and it does an amazing job of making a very mundane task appear thrilling and exciting. You start out as an immigration officer working in a border checkpoint of a communist country. The pay is abysmal and you have to provide for your whole family. When money's short, do you take bribes to keep you family fed and warm, or do you sacrifice their well-being for your own moral high ground? The game is full of such decisions that have long-lasting effects. The game starts with a simple task of checking entrant's passports then starts adding more and more rules to remember. Making more than two mistakes means you get fined, which can quicly drive you bankrupt. These challenges only make the gameplay more compelling though and you start to develop a sense of pride for your job. The constant narrative implications your actions have make for a very thrilling experience from the beginning to end.

The retro visual style of the game fits perfectly and adds a certain atmosphere to it that enhances the narrative setting. The soundtrack may be small in quantity, but the few tracks set the communist theme amazingly well.

The only real issue I had while playing this game was the repetitive nature of the gameplay, which I started to notice towards the end of the game. It is but a small blemish on an otherwise wonderful experience however.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Paperwork Simulator 1982, also known as Paper's, Please.
This game... How do I begin? The game itself begins by putting you in the shoes of a man who's been selected to serve on the border guard for the state of Arstotzka. It immediately puts you into your first day of work with little formality, where you spend your days poring over the documents of would be immigrants and visitors, determining whether they will make it in or not. As you go, situations will pop up, either forcing you personally to act or changing how your job is carried out. This tends to make life a little more difficult, more often than not. But do a good job- for every mistake or violation you make, Arstotzka will fine you.
You must balance the quality of your work with speed, however. For every person you screen and pass, you gain a little bit more in salary. You must rely on this salary to pay for the essentials of life for yourself and your family. You can pick and choose waht you need most, but be aware that if any one member of your family is deprived of anything for too long, they will likely die. Rent is a mandatory payment, however, and if that puts you in debt, you're done. Striaght to jail in the glourious Arstotzkan Penitentiary.
Papers, Please wasn't a game I expected to enjoy as much as I do. Just know that it will not only eat your free time, but that you won't be able to multitask with it. Trust me, I tried.
Glory to Arstotzka

reviewText:
Papers, Please is one of the most innovating and impressive games from this year. Being a sort of point-and-click game, Papers, Please excels in the way it uses it.

You take the role of an Arstotzkan border controller who regulates the border checkpoint in Grestin, Arstotzka.
You must earn money by doing your job accordingly and with as few errors as possible in order to feed and protect your family, as well as keeping them healthy and living under a roof.

The game focuses on the basic mechanics of point-and-click, but uses this mechanic in a very different way by allowing the player to check entrees' passports as they attempt to enter the country of Arstotzka. Your duty, as border controll, is to make sure that only people with valid documents enter the country.
If you make any errors, small amounts of your salary will be held back, and you may even allow in a terrorist if the person that you allowed entrance carried a bomb and you forgot to x-ray them because they had expired documents, for example.

The game has a very simple art direction, as well as a very simple sound design. Lucas Pope, the creator of the game, really nailed it with Papers, Please, as he created something inspiring, entertaining, and very different.

Papers, Please is one of its kind, and is one of those rare indie games that you should defnitely try out.

The only complaint I have is that the main story is too short, but even so, the game has a freemode and so you can continue to play on without focusing on the main story, even though the main story is crafted in a specific way and has its own events, the freemode is very fun too.

No more needs to be said.
Glory to Arstotzka.

reviewText: Played this at my friends with him and had a blast, got hte game myself to and I must say it is one of my top 5 games of 2013. What is with all these indie or early access games that are turning out better than 90% of the AAA games this year?\n\nAnyways, to the game, the atmosphere is well done, the gameplay is fun as hell and it is original. I think the only people who won't like this game are graphics who**** who only like games with beautiful graphics. This game is MUCH more than what you see, check it out! You have to investigate and check peoples passports at a check point. There can be terrorists,etc.. and as you get further into the game you have more things you can use to try and find the people who should not be in entering the country. I actually have felt bad a few times when I had to turn some people down. Very well made game and I hope the devs are working on another game in this series or another new game.

reviewText:
The most fascinating part of Papers, Please is how so much can spring from what looks like a boring desk job.

To be honest, you are doing approximately the same stuff every day, but there are so many subplots and rule changes going on that you always have something extra on your mind other than the paperwork you're checking. The game is also excellent for keeping you on edge and questioning your morals. You'd be surprised as to how many different endings the game has.

Cons: Half of the immigrants are complete idiots. Your boss is  an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  . The immigration inspector (main character) is sexist as he scans all crossdressers.  Never work for EZIC, as they will get u killed! .  CITATIONS . And finally terrorist attacks.

reviewText:
Just started playing this game and I'm really enjoying it. I bought the Humble Indie Bundle 12, again, just for this game and Prison Architect. (I payed $1 the first time, because I wasn't sure about the other games :P)

And I think they should make another game, but in another region, like Cuba or China. That'd be great, and I'd be the first to buy it! :D

10/10
