reviewText: A game for the ages, and seemingly made ages ago. Plain graphics with pixels a plenty; Papers, please is the simple, and yet addicting game that will separate itself from others. You micromanage by approving or denying citizens through passports and other documentation. Worth a try once you time the steam sales right.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Papers, Please is a strange game.  The gameplay is entirely monotonous: someone hands you documents, you cross check these documents against a set of ever changing rules, point out any discrepencies, repeat for several hours.  Despite the seeming simplicity, PP is incredibly addicting and I ended up completing it in a single sitting, something I haven't done with a video game (even short ones) since high school.\n\nMaybe it's the moody atmosphere that's as disturbing as it is darkly humorous.  Maybe it's the idea of having absolute authority over the lives of these virtual citizens.  Whatever the case, PP is worth every cent.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I’m not going to sit here and say Papers, Please is an artistic masterpiece, as those terms get thrown around far too often in this industry. The game isn’t perfect, but is more than interesting enough to overcome its downsides. If you’re looking for something truly unique in the modern swamp of AAA titles, Papers, Please will definitely fill that role. At $9.99, it’s a low-entry oddity that tells a compelling story about failure. And who knows? You might just experience a newfound perspective during your stay in Arstotzka.

reviewText:
This is a game I quit half-way through, probably never will play again, but yet recommend strongly.

As a foreword, bear in mind that I am an oversensitive wuss that gets uncomfortable by the random killing I commit when I play a GTA game.

The game puts you at the forefront of the misery and violence of the modern world : the visa check-in. It will resonnate strongly with whoever had to be familiar with such situation.
Fellow reviewer Brandon Cackowski-Schnell stated on multiple occasions he was amazed and scared at how the game turned him into a robotic mostly uncaring machine, just to protect those dear to him. In my case, the reaction was the exact opposite : I couldn't cope with the harshness of the job and so I did what I love to think I would have done in real life in such a position : I quit. (Please don't ask my in-game relatives what happened of them ;)

In that sense, as Dark Souls, I think it truly can be the closest you can get to a real role-playing game on a computer.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: In a world where many people don't realize a visa" isn't always a credit card
date: Papers Please seems like a pretty odd concept. A game where you stamp passports
recommended: being careful to abide by the ever-increasing rules and regulations of your dystopian public employers that are subject to the hopeless political climate of your war-torn and espionage-filled region
hoursPlayed: tends to stand out amongst the current plethora of green-lit retro platformers.\n\nDespite my own life-long love for a good sidescroller
voteText: I have to say Papers Please is the most engrossed I've been in a game in quite a while. When you're not lost in the bureaucratic fever dream of scanning each and every entrant's documentation - of which more and more will be required as time goes on and governments play dirtier - you're juggling funds for your family's food

date: you almost hate yourself for not noticing.\n\n10/10 BUY THIS GAME NOW FULL PRICE; if you're into that"

reviewText: This game tugged at my very sanity. It starts out normal enough, stopping terrorist, letting in citizens, but then you start getting these hard choices that question your virtues as a human. Like for example, a man gets through the border with no problem, then tells you that his wife was in line behind him. His wife comes by, and has expired papers. So then what.. do you reunite the couple, and let your family go hungry that night? It feels like theres no in way to help both, so the bottom line is, what kind of person are you? Amazing game overall.. 9.5/10, but I feel like they could add alot more.

reviewText:
Papers Please isn't like any other game. Papers Please has a amazing story with unique gameplay centred around a job at border control. But as the game continues so does the story and you have many different interactions. Its great because a very small act can send you to the top or can send you to jail. The best thing is the moral choices such as: do you take a bribe and risk being caught? Do you buy medicine for your child or heat the house?
The game seems very basic and boring at the start but as you play on it becomes much more interesting.

Final Verdict: 9/10

reviewText:
Going into Papers Please I didn't expect much, and what I got was a very well thought out game. Which, in my opinion, is one of the best games I have ever played.

The game is set in a fictional country called Arstotska, and you have the job of being border control. You let immigrants into the country and if they don't have valid paperwork you send them on their way (later in the game you get the option to detain them). This is what I saw in the trailer, so I figured this was one of the boring of the dozens of simulators that are out on the market. So I started the game up, and realized that it was 3 in the morning.

I wouldn't say that this is a fun game, but rather I very entertaining and tense game that gets you very well intrigued with the other countless stories of other immigrants that come into your country. The stress that comes with making enough money each day to keep your family healthy is something that not even Dark Souls could replicate with it's teeth grinding difficulty. Your job becomes more and more difficult as the rules constantly change and you have to check more paperwork until your desk is flooded with it. The last couple of hours were the tense I've had in gaming for a long time. For the cons of this game, well, I can't really think of any. The only thing that comes to mind is the paperwork does become a bit less interesting by the end of the game, and becomes more of a task.

Overall I very much recommend this game, and if you haven't already, buy this game. You will be amazed at how good a paperwork simulator actually is.

reviewText: This is probably my game of the year. I'm not sure why it keeps bringing me back. It is, objectively, very repetitive. I'm sure someone more eloquent than me can go one about the various questions about society the story raises. Highly recommend!

reviewText: First things first: Don't be fooled by the ancient graphics circa 1990.  This game is an exciting title in all the sense of the world.  Your skills will be tested,  your loyalty will be tested, and even your principles will.\n\nYou play as a boder employee, in charge of entry to Arstotzka.   Your duties are to check if applicants meet the current requirements to enter, but it doesn't end there.  You'll face terrorist attacks, criminals and people that rely on you to break the rules (or not) to help them.  In a nutshell, your decisions have some actual weight in this title.  High replay value, entertaining and absolutely recommended.  10/10

reviewText:
Papers, Please is a very good game. It might not seem like it (Due to the fact that mostly all you do is press stamps on paperwork) but believe me, there is MUCH, MUCH more to this game. It has the perfect Dystopia. And it gets very interesting from time to time. For example, terrorist attacks could occur. A secret rebel organization bribes you in many differen't ways to convince into supporting their actions into destroying the corrupt government.

You can interrorgate people by having their pictures taken on a body scanner (Which could unvail some disturbing things the entrant might not want you to discover) such as having guns strapped on their backs, and even contraband strapped onto their legs, etc.

The bottom line is, this game has a lot of potential. There is even an excessive number of endings you could get (A little bit over 40 to be exact), to keep you more interested. 10/10

reviewText: If you like retro-gaming and hidden-object games -- this is a great take on the genre. You play a Check-point Charlie" -- a person who checks papers crossing the border of a progressively authoritarian regime. You must work as fast as possible (or your family will starve or worse) as well as thoroughly (not careful enough and not only will your pathetic pay be docked
date: but you may be sanctioned or let terrorists into the country!)\n\nIt's a very rich game narratively
recommended: and you have a great deal of freedom to act for somebody stuck in a box the whole game. You can support resistance or state oppression
hoursPlayed: grift or keep your nose clean
voteText: or just do your job and not stick your neck out. The game has 20 endings and only a couple I found were pleasant. Good fun -- I was surprised how sucked into the game I got!"
